forage for wild herbs and plants: One approach to treating a common cold in a world without medication would be to forage for wild herbs and plants with known healing properties. For example, mint, eucalyptus, and echinacea have all been used for centuries to alleviate cold and flu symptoms. Gathering these plants and using them in teas, tinctures, or salves could provide some relief from the symptoms of a common cold.

Try steam inhalation: Steam inhalation has long been used as a natural remedy for respiratory issues, including the common cold. By boiling water and inhaling the steam, mucus and congestion can be loosened, making it easier to breathe. This can be done using a humidifier or by boiling water in a pot and inhaling the steam directly.

Use honey as a cough suppressant: Honey has been used for centuries as a natural cough suppressant and expectorant. It can be mixed with warm water or tea to help soothe a sore throat and reduce coughing. Honey also has antibacterial properties, which could help combat the underlying infection causing the cold.

Practice good hygiene: Good hygiene practices, such as washing hands frequently, avoiding close contact with others, and covering the mouth and nose when coughing, can help prevent the spread of the common cold. By reducing the transmission of the virus, it may be possible to reduce the number of colds that occur in a given population.

Try acupuncture: Acupuncture is a traditional Chinese medicine technique that involves inserting small needles into specific points on the body to stimulate healing and balance. Some studies have suggested that acupuncture may help alleviate cold and flu symptoms by boosting the immune system and reducing inflammation. This could be a viable alternative to medication for treating the common cold in a world without drugs.
